items.description: Tidal Thames riverside from Putney Bridge to Teddington Weir
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex

floodArea.county: Greater London, Hammersmith and Fulham, Hounslow, Richmond upon Thames, Wandsworth

items.message:
River levels are expected to be high as a result of spring tides.

The forecast high tide at Richmond is 4.81mAOD at 06:45 on 24/08/24 and 4.70mAOD at 18:45 on 24/08/24.

Flooding of low-lying roads and footpaths is expected, which may exist for one to two hours either side of high tide. Flooding of properties is not expected.

We believe there is a possibility of flooding for Putney Embankment (SW15), Chiswick Mall and Strand on the Green (W4), Thames Bank at Mortlake (SW14), Ranelagh Drive (TW1), Friars Lane and Water Lane (TW9), Riverside and The Embankment at Twickenham, and the Towpath below Teddington Lock. 

Astronomical tide levels are falling. The river flow at Teddington Weir is normal for this time of year at 19 cubic metres per second and is steady. We anticipate the flows to remain normal for the next few days.

We are closely monitoring the situation.

This message will be updated by 20:00 on 24/08/24, or as the situation changes.

items.description: North Devon coast from Hartland Point to Lynmouth
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message: The risk of flooding from the sea has now reduced and tide levels are falling below levels of concern. No further flooding is expected, however, please take care near coastal paths and promenades.

items.description: Wye Estuary in Gloucestershire
items.message:
This Flood Alert has been removed.  
  There is no longer a threat of flooding, though standing water and debris may still remain.  
We continue to monitor the situation.  Our incident response staff are checking the condition of defences.  
Please avoid contact with flood water.

items.description: Mersey Estuary at Warrington
Irish Sea from Hilbre Island to Heswall
North Sea coast at Withernsea, Easington and Kilnsea
items.message: This flood Alert remains in force due to strong winds, surge, and high spring tides on the coast tomorrow morning, Sunday 25/08/2024. Areas most at risk include low lying land and roads in the Spurn Road, Southfield Farm and Kilnsea Caravan park areas. Flooding of coastal roads and footpaths along coast frontages is likely. Flooding is possible between 9.00am and 11:00am tomorrow, Sunday 25/08/2024. We are expecting higher than normal tides over the next few days and as a result we may issue further alerts or warnings. We are closely monitoring the situation. Be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads, as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous. This message will be updated by 9.00am on Sunday 25/08/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Tidal River Avon at Bristol, Pill and Shirehampton

floodArea.county: City of Bristol, North Somerset, South Gloucestershire

items.message:
There is no longer a threat of flooding, though standing water and debris may still remain.
There may still be some areas where flood water is present until it can naturally drain away.
We will continue to monitor the situation and will issue further alerts or warnings if necessary.
Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger.
Don't put yourself or others at risk.

items.description: Climping Seafront
items.message: Sunday's early morning tide at 04:00 on 25/08/2024 is forecast to be lower than recent days, and accompanied by light South Westerly Force 5 winds. Light winds and small waves are forecast, and with tides lower, no more than minimal flood impacts are expected over the next five days. We continue to monitor the forecast. We will reissue this Flood Alert if the risk of flooding increases.

items.description: The Essex coast at Coalhouse Fort
items.message: Levels are now below the flood risk thresholds. The forecast is for no current flood risk from high tides. Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We will continue to monitor levels closely.

items.description: Tyne estuary

floodArea.county: Gateshead, Newcastle upon Tyne, North Tyneside, South Tyneside

items.message:
High tides are expected due to a combination of high spring tides and a storm surge following Storm Lilian. Strong winds may cause large waves within the estuary tomorrow morning, 23/08/2024. Tides will be at their highest between 05:15 and 07:15, 23/08/2024 with wave overtopping possible during these times. The area most likely to be affected is Newcastle Quayside.
 
This alert is in force for the this evenings high tide, Thursday (22/08/2024) Friday mornings tide (23/08/2024), and Saturday mornings tide (24/08/24). 
High tides are anticipated between 17:30 and 19:30, 22/08/2024, 05:15 and 07:15, 23/08/2024 and 06:00 and 08:00 24/08/2024. The flood risk impacts will be highest on the Friday morning tide, 23/08/2024. Please remain vigilant for any potential flood warnings around Newcastle Quayside.
 
We will continue to monitor levels closely. Please stay away from riverside footpaths and low lying land and roads as high water levels, large waves and sea spray could be dangerous.
 
This message will be updated by 11:00AM on 24/08/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Humber estuary from Spurn Point to Winestead Outfall
items.message: This flood Alert remains in force due to strong winds, surge, and high spring tides on the coast tomorrow morning, Sunday 25/08/2024 and over the coming days. Areas most at risk include The Humber estuary from Spurn Point to Winestead Outfall. Flooding of coastal roads is possible between 8:30am and 12:00 pm tomorrow, Sunday, 25/08/2024. We are closely monitoring the situation. Be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads. This message will be updated by 9.00am on Sunday 25/08/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Rivers Brathay, Rothay and Winster

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Brathay, River Rothay, River Winster

items.message:
River and lake levels in the area will remain high due to recent rainfall.  We are expecting a drier day today with occasional showers,  meaning levels will fall throughout today 24/08/2024.  We are expecting further rain Sunday 25/8/24 which will keep levels higher than normal but we are not expecting this to cause any increase to current levels. 

Areas most at risk include Rivers Brathay, Rothay and Winster and other watercourses, from Grasmere to Grange-over-Sands including low lying areas around Ambleside, Skelwith Bridge, Windermere, Hawkshead, Newby Bridge, Backbarrow, Cark and Cartmel. Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water.

This message will be updated by 10:00 AM on 25/08/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Upper River Derwent, Stonethwaite Beck and Derwent Water
items.message:
River and lake levels in the area will remain high due to recent rainfall.  We are expecting a drier day today with occasional showers,  meaning levels will fall throughout today 24/08/2024.  We are expecting further rain Sunday 25/8/24 which will keep levels higher than normal but we are not expecting this to cause any increase to current levels.

Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the Upper River Derwent, Stonethwaite Beck and Derwent Water, with low lying land and roads expected to be most affected, particularly around The Upper Derwent from Seathwaite to Derwent Water.  Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water.

This message will be updated by 10:00 AM on 25/08/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Keswick Campsite
items.message:
Lake levels will remain high due to recent rainfall.  We are expecting a drier day today with occasional showers,  meaning levels will fall throughout today 24/08/2024.  We are expecting further rain Sunday 25/8/24 which will keep levels higher than normal but we are not expecting this to cause any increase to current levels.

Areas most at risk include low lying areas bordering the shores of Derwent Water and the frontage of the Keswick Camping and Caravan Club SiteÂ  .

We are closely monitoring the situation and liaising with campsite staff.  

Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water.

This message will be updated by 10:00 AM on 25/08/2024, or as the situation changes.
